discussion.content:
B -> if RETENTION GRANTEE, it will let lack of space in the undo tablespace
D -> NOGUARANTEE -> it won't have lack of space so it may overwrite
THe answer is D

choices.B: Inactive undo data is retained for 1200 seconds even if subsequent transactions fail due to lack of space in the undo tablespace.
choices.D: An attempt is made to keep inactive undo for 1200 seconds but transactions may overwrite the undo before that time has elapsed.
choices.A: Undo data is written to flashback logs after 1200 seconds.
choices.C: You can perform a Flashback Database operation only within the duration of 1200 seconds.

You can, for example select, join, or sort external table data. You can also create views and synonyms for external tables. However, no DML operations
(UPDATE, INSERT, or DELETE) are possible, and no indexes can be created, on external tables.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
In some cases, there are other techniques available to improve estimation; for instance, dynamic sampling or multi-column statistics allow the optimizer to more accurately estimate selectivity of conjunctive predicates. In cases where these techniques apply, statistics feedback is not enabled.

D is correct: cardinality feedback is called Statistics feedback in 12c. "In some cases, there are other techniques available to improve estimation; for instance, dynamic sampling or multi-column statistics allow the optimizer to more accurately estimate selectivity of conjunctive predicates. In cases where these techniques apply, statistics feedback is not enabled. However, if multi-column statistics are not present for the relevant combination of columns, the optimizer can fall back on statistics feedback."
Reference: https://blogs.oracle.com/optimizer/post/statistics-feedback-formerly-cardinality-feedback

Selected Answer: ACE
So given answer D is wrong. E is correct.
A C E.
Any comment please.

I Think A C E.
CF(cardinality feedback) is helping Dynamic sampling. In order to disable CF. You need to set _optimizer_use_feedback" to false at a session or statement level.
So given answer D is wrong. E is correct.

choices.E: After the optimizer identifies a query as a re-optimization candidate, statistics collected by the collectors are submitted to the optimizer.
choices.B: The optimizer can re optimize a query only once using cardinality feedback.
choices.A: The optimizer automatically changes a plan during subsequent execution of a SQL statement if there is a huge difference in optimizer estimates and execution statistics.
choices.D: The optimizer does not monitor cardinality feedback if dynamic sampling and multicolumn statistics are enabled.
choices.C: The optimizer enables monitoring for cardinality feedback after the first execution of a query.

questions.answer_description:
C: During the first execution of a SQL statement, an execution plan is generated as usual.
D: if multi-column statistics are not present for the relevant combination of columns, the optimizer can fall back on cardinality feedback.
(not B)* Cardinality feedback. This feature, enabled by default in 11.2, is intended to improve plans for repeated executions. optimizer_dynamic_sampling optimizer_features_enable
* dynamic sampling or multi-column statistics allow the optimizer to more accurately estimate selectivity of conjunctive predicates.
Note:
* OPTIMIZER_DYNAMIC_SAMPLING controls the level of dynamic sampling performed by the optimizer.

Range of values. 0 to 10 -
* Cardinality feedback was introduced in Oracle Database 11gR2. The purpose of this feature is to automatically improve plans for queries that are executed repeatedly, for which the optimizer does not estimate cardinalities in the plan properly. The optimizer may misestimate cardinalities for a variety of reasons, such as missing or inaccurate statistics, or complex predicates. Whatever the reason for the misestimate, cardinality feedback may be able to help.

questions.question_text:
Which three statements are true when the listener handles connection requests to an Oracle 12c database instance with multithreaded architecture enabled In
UNIX? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B10500_01/server.920/a96544/multithr.htm

In the architecture for multithreaded agents, each incoming connection request is processed by means of the three different kinds of threads:

A single monitor thread (SCMN thread) (option D)

The monitor thread is responsible for the following:

-Maintaining communication with the listener
-Monitoring the load on the process
-Starting and stopping threads when required
-Several dispatcher threads

The dispatcher threads are responsible for the following:

-Handling communication with the Oracle server (option A)
-Passing task requests on to the task threads

Several task threads

-The task threads handle requests from the Oracle processes.

When a SCMN thread registers the dispatcher threads it has created with all the listeners that are handling connections to this agent.
While the dispatcher for this SID is running, the listener does not start a new process when it gets an incoming connection. Instead, the listener hands over the connection to this same dispatcher. (option E)

choices.A: Thread creation must be routed through a dispatcher process
choices.E: The local listener may pass the request to an existing process which in turn will create a thread.
choices.B: The local listener may spawn a now process and have that new process create a thread
choices.D: Each multithreaded Oracle process has an SCMN thread.
choices.C: Each Oracle process runs an SCMN thread.

choices.B: It fails because common users are unable to use the SET CONTAINER statement.
choices.D: If fails because the SET CONTAINER statement cannot be used with PDB$SEED as the target pluggable database (PDB).
choices.C: It fails because local users are unable to use the SET CONTAINER statement.
choices.A: It succeeds because the PDB_ADMIN user has the required privileges.

discussion.content:
Answer is C:

SQL> create pluggable database cdb1pdb3 admin user cdb1pdb3_admin identified by password file_name_convert=(‘/oradata/CDB1/pdbseed’,’/oradata/CDB1/CDB1PDB3′) ;

Pluggable database created.

SQL> alter pluggable database cdb1pdb3 open;

Pluggable database altered.

SQL> alter session set container=cdb1pdb3
2 /

Session altered.

SQL> grant connect to cdb1pdb3_admin;

Grant succeeded.

SQL> connect cdb1pdb3_admin/password@nonrac12c-oel6u5/cdb1pdb3
Connected.
SQL> select * from session_privs;

PRIVILEGE
—————————————-
SET CONTAINER
CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE
CREATE SESSION

SQL> alter session set container=PDB$SEED;
ERROR:
ORA-01031: insufficient privileges

SQL>

Selected Answer: C
Local user shouldn't able to access another PDBs or CDB
